似乎每家公司都在争先恐后地在人工智能淘金热中占据一席之地—— 克罗格的首席执行官承诺将法学硕士带入乳制品领域。一线工作人员也在效仿——尝试人工智能，以便他们可以更快地工作并做得更多。

自 ChatGPT 推出以来的短短几个月内，市场上已经出现了数百种人工智能驱动的工具。但是，虽然基于人工智能的工具具有真正有用的应用程序，但它们也带来了严重的安全风险。不幸的是，大多数公司仍然没有拿出管理这些风险的政策。在缺乏关于负责任的人工智能使用的明确指导的情况下，员工会漫不经心地将敏感数据交给不值得信赖的工具。

基于人工智能的浏览器扩展最清楚地说明了这一现象。 Chrome 商店中充斥着（声称）利用 ChatGPT 执行各种任务的扩展：发送电子邮件、设计图形、转录会议和编写代码。但这些工具容易出现至少三种类型的风险。

  1. 恶意软件：安全研究人员不断发现窃取用户数据的基于人工智能的扩展。这些扩展程序利用了用户对大型科技平台的信任（“如果 Google 允许它出现在 Chrome 商店中，那不会有危险！”），而且它们通常通过连接 ChatGPT 等人的 API 来发挥作用。
  2. 数据治理：包括苹果和威瑞森在内的公司已禁止其员工使用法学硕士，因为这些产品很少能保证用户的输入不会被用作培训数据。
  3. 即时注入攻击：在这种鲜为人知但可能无法解决的攻击中，网页上的隐藏文本指示人工智能工具执行恶意操作，例如窃取数据，然后删除记录。

到目前为止，大多数公司都被人工智能打了个措手不及，但这些风险太严重了，不容忽视。

在 Kolide，我们采用两部分方法来管理人工智能的使用。

  1. 以团队形式起草人工智能政策。我们不想完全禁止我们的团队使用人工智能，我们只是想安全地使用它。因此，我们的第一步是与多个团队的代表会面，了解他们从基于人工智能的工具中获得了什么，以及我们如何为他们提供不暴露关键数据或基础设施的安全选项。
  2. 使用 Kolide 阻止恶意工具。 Kolide 让 IT 和安全团队编写检测设备合规性问题的检查，我们已经开始为基于人工智能的恶意（或可疑）工具创建检查。现在，如果员工不小心下载了恶意软件，他们将无法登录我们的云应用程序，直到他们将其删除。

每家公司都必须根据自己独特的需求和关注点制定政策，但重要的是现在就开始。在人工智能卷走你公司的数据之前，我们还有时间抓住它的控制权。

entry.summary: 在运动方面，Pro型号是进攻，非Pro型号是防守。他们说，赢得冠军的是防守。
entry.content:
2017 年， iPhone X标志着 iPhone 历史上一个明显的转折点：从最初的 Home 键系统界面（带有 Touch ID）切换到带有 Face ID 的“全屏”界面。但这也标志着苹果年度 iPhone 硬件战略的一个广泛误解/低估（尽管我很痛苦地指出，并非全部）的变化。 2017 年，苹果开始每年推出两款完全不同级别的新 iPhone，而不是只推出一款新 iPhone。一位“专业”，一位“常规”：

专业版常规的
2017年X/A11 8 / A11
2018年XS/A12 XR/A12
2019年11 Pro/A13 11 / A13
2020年12 Pro/A14 12 / A14
2021年13 Pro / A15 13 / A15
2022年14 Pro / A16 14 / A15
2023年15 Pro/A17 15 / A16

（对于今年的模型，最后一行在撰写本文时是推测性的，但似乎有可能。）

该表并未考虑同一级别（Mini / Max / Plus）内的不同尺寸，但这些实际上只是相同基本 iPhone 的不同尺寸。真正的区别在于专业型号和非专业型号之间。苹果直到 2019 年 iPhone 11 才开始将 iPhone 命名为“Pro”，但实际上，他们在 2017 年通过 X 开始了这一“专业”级别。

每个人都对这一策略感到不满的是，专业型号的价格更高。当然是。但许多人忽视了苹果战略的一些方面。最重要的是，iPhone Pro 机型的生产期限仅为一年。如果这种模式成立，那么下周，iPhone 14 Pro和Pro Max将停止生产，并在产品线中被新的15 Pro机型取代。然而，非专业版 iPhone 的生产时间至少还要延长两年，价格每年下降 100 美元。我觉得这很有趣，但很少有人注意到。最昂贵、最先进、而且我认为最难制造的 iPhone 只生产一年。这是 iPhone X 之前的一种全新策略，当时每年只有一款新的旗舰 iPhone（尽管在 iPhone 6-6S-7 年间有两种尺寸），并且大多数 iPhone 都以降价形式保留在产品阵容中。未来几年。

因此，虽然有报道称去年的 iPhone 14 Plus 销量不是特别好，但这并不意味着它是失败的，甚至不意味着苹果预计它去年的销量会那么好。对我来说，非专业 iPhone 的主力年份是产品线的第二年和第三年，那时它们的价格会下降。人们购买较便宜的 iPhone 但想要大屏幕的人以前从未有过选择：现在已经上市一年的 iPhone 14 Plus 就是这样的选择。

去年一个引人注目的变化是，非专业版 iPhone 14 机型自 2021 年起仍采用 A15 芯片。一个不太引人注目的变化是，iPhone 14 与 iPhone 13 在内部有很大不同，尽管两者都使用 A15 芯片。相同的A15芯片。 iFixit 将 iPhone 14（非专业型号）描述为苹果有史以来最容易维修的 iPhone。芯片保持不变，但内部设计完全不同，而且更好。 iPhone 14 的设计本应在未来几年内继续生产。

明天我们不知道这种更可修复、更易于访问的系统架构是否会在 iPhone 15 上重复，但我怀疑它会的。无论如何，常规的 iPhone 15 机型将不仅仅是 iPhone 14 Pro 机型重新包装为铝制框架而不是不锈钢。在我看来，苹果已经实现的战略是：

  • 专业机型：尖端芯片、摄像头、材料；生产期限仅为一年。
  • 非专业型号：使用一年前的SoC和旧相机系统的精致架构；将在发布年份后生产 2-3 年。

iPhone Pro 更令人兴奋，但非 Pro iPhone 对于该产品线乃至整个 iPhone 生态系统至关重要。在运动方面，Pro型号是进攻，非Pro型号是防守。他们说，进攻赢得荣耀，但防守才能赢得冠军。

;
entry.title: ★ 苹果双管齐下的年度 iPhone 战略
至少“疯狂”这个词很合适
entry.content:
CNBC 摘录了沃尔特·艾萨克森 (Walter Isaacson) 的埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk)的另一段摘录，讲述了马斯克和他的表兄弟将数千台服务器从萨克拉门托的一个数据中心迁移到波特兰的另一个数据中心的故事：

“你必须聘请承包商来抬起地板，”亚历克斯说。 “它们需要用吸盘来举起。”他说，另一组承包商必须进入地板下方并断开电缆和地震杆。

马斯克转向他的保安，要求借用他的小刀。使用它，他能够抬起地板上的一个通风口，这使他能够撬开地板面板。然后他自己爬到服务器地板下，用刀撬开电气柜，拔掉服务器插头，然后等着看会发生什么。什么都没有爆炸。服务器已准备好移动。

“嗯，这看起来并不难，”他说道，乌兹别克人亚历克斯和其他人都盯着看。马斯克对此非常兴奋。他大声笑着说，这就像翻拍的《碟中谍》萨克拉门托版。

一切都是一堆令人厌恶的事情，直到它变成了令人厌恶的事情：

服务器上有用户数据，詹姆斯最初并没有意识到，出于隐私原因，它们应该在移动之前被清除干净。 “当我们了解到这一点时，服务器已经被拔掉并推出，因此我们无法将它们回滚，插入，然后擦除它们，”他说。另外，擦除软件无法运行。 “妈的，我们该怎么办？”他问。埃隆建议他们锁定卡车并跟踪它们。

因此，詹姆斯派人去家得宝购买大挂锁，然后他们将电子表格上的密码发送到波特兰，以便在那里打开卡车。 “我不敢相信它有效，”詹姆斯说。 “他们都安全抵达波特兰。”

在某种程度上，深刻的紧迫感对领导者是有益的。尽管 CNBC 有这样的框架，但马斯克显然已经远远超出了这一点。整个努力是荒谬且不必要的鲁莽。除了侵犯隐私之外，不顾 Twitter 基础设施团队的直接建议将这些服务器从萨克拉门托撤出，还直接导致用户数月的不稳定。

★

entry.title: 高通宣布与苹果续签 5G 调制解调器协议
entry.content:
伊恩·金 (Ian King) 和马克·古尔曼 (Mark Gurman) 为彭博社报道：

苹果公司(Apple Inc.)将从高通公司(Qualcomm Inc.)获得调制解调器半导体的协议再延长三年，这表明该公司内部设计芯片的雄心勃勃的努力所花费的时间比预期的要长。消息传出后，高通股价飙升。

高通在周一的一份声明中表示，新协议将涵盖“2024 年、2025 年和 2026 年推出的智能手机”。两家公司的协议原定于今年结束，预计将于周二发布的最新款 iPhone 将是最后一批依赖高通调制解调器芯片的 iPhone 之一。 […]

这家总部位于圣地亚哥的芯片制造商表示：“这项协议巩固了高通在 5G 技术和产品方面持续领先的记录。”尽管新协议的财务条款尚未披露，但高通表示，这与 2019 年签署的先前协议类似。

有趣的是他们今天宣布了这一消息，更有趣的是苹果公司没有任何人引用这一消息。高通似乎在 5G 调制解调器方面对苹果发起了挑战。

更新：请记住，苹果多年来一直在尝试构建自己的 5G 调制解调器。早在 2019 年，他们就收购了英特尔的调制解调器业务，同年他们与高通达成和解（实际上是败诉） 。今年夏天发生了这样的故事，苹果指控高通骚扰苹果高管，并传唤他们向联邦贸易委员会提起诉讼。这两家公司互不喜欢对方。

★

Yoko Kubota， 《华尔街日报》周三在北京报道（新闻+链接）：

知情人士称，中国命令中央政府机构官员不得在工作中使用苹果 iPhone 和其他外国品牌设备，也不得将其带入办公室。

知情人士称，最近几周，员工在工作场所聊天群或会议中收到了上级的指示。该指令是北京减少对外国技术依赖并加强网络安全的最新举措，同时中国正寻求限制敏感信息在中国境外的流动。北京此举可能会对包括苹果在内的在华外国品牌产生寒蝉效应。苹果在中国高端智能手机市场占据主导地位，并将中国视为其最大的市场之一，约占其总收入的 19%。

珍妮·伦纳德 (Jenny Leonard) 和黛比·吴 (Debby Wu) 周四为彭博社1报道：

中国计划将敏感部门使用 iPhone 的禁令扩大到政府支持的机构和国有企业，这表明苹果公司在其最大的国外市场和全球生产基地面临着越来越大的挑战。

知情人士称，一些机构已开始指示员工不要携带 iPhone 上班，这证实了《华尔街日报》之前的报道。此外，因讨论敏感问题而要求匿名的知情人士表示，北京还打算将这一限制范围扩大到更多国有企业和其他政府控制的组织。

[ Inside Baseball Interpolation ：我经常在这里提到，彭博社作为一家新闻机构，对独家新闻有着独特的狂热——第一个报道新闻，尤其是影响市场的新闻。当新闻在其他地方重新报道时，他们希望自己的独家新闻得到赞扬。所以相信我，他们将这一独家新闻归功于《华尔街日报》，这让他们很痛苦。但这就是彭博机构的白痴暴露的地方：查看上面引用中“报告”一词的链接。提示：它与爆料该消息的《华尔街日报》报道没有链接。]

如果北京继续实施，史无前例的封锁将是多年来根除外国技术在敏感环境中使用的努力的顶峰，同时北京也在努力减少对美国软件和电路的依赖。

这引起了我对这项法令的强烈好奇心。其中有多少是民族主义——中共对警察国家固有的沙文主义心态进行了调整——有多少（如果有的话）是因为iPhone是安全的，而它们的安全超出了政府的能力范围。中共？中国政府肯定希望监视政府雇员在手机上的行为，而 iPhone 让这变得更加困难。

最后，苹果与中国政府的独特关系在哪里发挥了作用？苹果公司仍然依赖中国制造，尤其是iPhone。他们在其他地方生产一些iPhone ，但绝大多数是在中国组装的，目前世界上没有其他供应链可以取代它。对于任何谈判来说，这都是一个糟糕的起点。但是：中国从苹果那里得到了很多。在我的一生中，中国一直在努力改变人们对“中国制造”的看法。它总是意味着便宜。它曾经也意味着粗制滥造。苹果是中国帽子上的羽毛。 iPhone 不仅是世界上最好的手机，而且可以说是所有类别中最好、最复杂的量产消费品。而且它们几乎完全是在中国制造的。

中国政府肯定对华为在全球的贱民地位感到愤怒，但任何中国公司都不可能获得苹果那样的声誉。华为手机充其量就是三流，这是所有人都知道的，包括中国的所有人。 2如果中国保持与苹果的共生关系，中国将与世界上最负盛名的科技品牌保持牢固的联系。如果不是这样，苹果公司将其主要制造转移到其他地方，中国将再次下降到只与二流和三流产品联系在一起。更糟糕的是，在这种情况下，最好的公司也会选择放弃中国。中国从苹果公司获得了巨大的声誉；苹果公司因其对残酷侵犯人权的共产主义独裁政权的依赖而受到声誉打击。

也许中国认为苹果无法消除对中国制造的依赖，所以可以随意对抗苹果。但即使这是真的，向其他考虑转向中国组装的公司（例如汽车制造商）传达的信息是：一旦你变得越来越依赖中国，我们就会像对待苹果公司一样对待你。中国想要向世界传达的信息不仅是中国是最有制造能力的国家，而且是值得信赖和可靠的合作伙伴。

苹果公司针对政府雇员使用 iPhone 的行为提出了相反的观点：中国作为合作伙伴不值得信任。

这就是我计算缓和情况的方法。如果苹果能够摆脱对中国制造的依赖，他们可能会这样做。但这样做的风险在于，这样做会惹恼习近平政权，而苹果公司在中国的消费品销售也会受到影响。 （也许这就是我们现在所看到的？）

但如果苹果真的放松对中国的依赖，中国可以用谁来取代他们呢？他们能把谁吹捧为依赖中国制造的世界级科技公司呢？第二名落后苹果太远了，你看不到它。

entry.title: 印第安纳圆周率法案
entry.content:
维基百科：

《印第安纳圆周率法案》是 1897 年印第安纳州议会第 246 号法案的俗称，该法案是通过立法命令确立数学真理的最臭名昭著的尝试之一。尽管它的名字如此，该法案声称的主要结果是一种化圆为方的方法，尽管它确实暗示了数学常数π（圆的周长与其直径的比值）的各种错误值。该法案由一位业余数学家医生撰写，由于普渡大学 CA Waldo 教授的干预而从未成为法律，而在该法案进行投票的当天，他恰好在立法机关。

这里有一个很好的总结（来自现代普渡大学教授 Edray Goins），讲述了这个怪人 Edwin Goodwin 如何得出 π = 3.2。

一位朋友评论英国放弃强制检查不可能检查的端到端消息传递的鲁莽尝试，这让我想起了这项可笑的立法* 。 E2EE 通信无法“扫描”儿童色情内容，同时保持所有其他目的的安全，但如果可以的话那就太好了。 Pi 不是 3.2，圆也不能平方，但如果能平方就好了。英国的立法与一个多世纪前印第安纳州的立法一样，都是无知的一厢情愿。

然而，印第安纳州的这项法案并没有被否决——它显然只是被搁置了。同样，英国还没有废除赋予他们有效禁止端到端加密权力的法律——他们只是宣布不会使用它。那很危险。这条法律应该被废除，而不是被忽视。

*沃尔多 (Waldo) 本人对这一传奇故事的描述中有一段关于向古德温 (Goodwin) 提出的提议的精彩引文（以第三人称写）：“一名成员向作者展示了一份刚刚通过的法案副本，并询问他是否愿意我想要介绍一位博学的医生，即它的作者。他拒绝了这种礼貌，并表示感谢，并表示他认识了很多他想认识的疯子。”

阿门，沃尔多博士。

entry.title: 烂番茄烂了
entry.content:
莱恩·布朗 (Lane Brown) 为 Vulture 撰文：

尽管烂番茄享有盛誉，但还是值得提醒一下：它的数学很糟糕。分数的计算方法是将每条评论分为正面或负面，然后将正面数量除以总数。这就是整个公式。无论是在主要报纸上还是在拥有十几个订阅者的 Substack 上发表，每条评论都具有相同的权重。

如果评论横跨正面和负面，那就太糟糕了。 “我读过一些对我自己的电影的评论，其中作者可能会说他认为我没有成功，但是，天哪，我没有成功，这很有趣吗？”施拉德说，前批评家。 “对我来说，这是一篇很好的评论，但在烂番茄上它会被视为负面评论。” [...]

另一个问题——也是骗局经常开始的地方——是，烂番茄评分是在电影只收到少量评论后发布的，有时只有五个评论，即使这些评论可能是不具有代表性的样本。这有点像有线新闻网络在单个县报告结果后宣布选举之夜获胜者。但电影公司将其视为一个特色，因为，只需一点点努力，他们有时就能愚弄人们，让他们相信电影比实际情况更好。

布朗还发现了隐性报酬，一家好莱坞公关公司向烂番茄追踪的小批评家支付 50 美元（五十块钱！）以获得正面评价。多年来，我全家人对烂番茄的评分越来越怀疑，但今年早些时候，当我们租了《M3gan》时，我们达到了临界点，我们都认为这是一部糟糕的电影，但烂番茄的得分为 93 分。 （ Metacritic 的“普遍好评”为 72。 ）

Facebook 母公司 Meta 旗下的 WhatsApp 和另一款流行的加密通讯应用 Signal 均威胁称，如果它们被勒令削弱加密功能，它们将退出英国市场。加密是一种广泛使用的安全技术，只允许消息的发送者和接收者进行操作。查看消息的内容。 [...]

据几位了解政府想法的人士透露，官员们私下向科技公司承认，目前还没有一种技术能够扫描端到端加密消息，同时又不会损害用户的隐私。

这并不是关于加密和立法者关于“只有好人才能访问的后门”的幻想的最糟糕的报告，但它从根本上具有误导性。端到端加密的含义就在它的名字中。没有可以从“弱”到“强”调节的旋钮。端点之间没有内容检查选项。这并不是选择不允许窃听者，而是实施技术上无法检查发送者和接收者之间的内容的协议。

实际的数学要复杂得多，但最终归结为英国承认 2 + 2 只能等于 4。

entry.title: Horace Dediu：“客户的价值”
entry.content:
Horace Dediu 在新近焕然一新的 Asymco 上写道：

这样图片就变得更清晰了。 iPhone 客户的价值是 Android 客户的7.4 倍。这比我 10 年前的 4× 规则更令人印象深刻。原因主要是我的轶事来自在美国或欧盟销售产品的开发商，而智能手机向全球 70 亿用户的扩张吸引了更多低消费客户。

但苹果的用户群也已增长至超过 10 亿（6.5 亿商店用户）。这凸显出苹果公司有效地发展和区分了客户。它不仅获得了10亿客户，而且获得了最好的10亿客户。

如何有效区分是营销的圣杯。天真的做法是保持高价格。但这通常只会导致“豪华”品牌和往往无法增长的小基数。另一种“高级”方法是提供功能、多层、分销选项以及融资和销售。没有简单的公式。

我真的很喜欢这篇文章，但我会质疑“没有简单的公式”。执行起来既困难又复杂。但从高层次来看，苹果公司为 iPhone（和 iPad）取得空前成功而采用的公式非常简单。

首先，做一些人们深切关心的事情。计算机是工业革命以来人类社会最大的进步；革命是一个很强烈的词，但它在当时适用，在今天也同样适用。人们非常关心他们的计算机以及他们在计算机上所做的事情，并且他们最关心最个人化的个人计算机：他们的手机。他们将其用于通信、摄影、娱乐（音乐和视频）、游戏等。他们几乎每天都带着它们去任何地方，并睡在它们旁边。

其次，为人们深切关心的事情制作最好的版本。最关心的人会认识到你的产品的优越性，并乐意（而不是勉强）为此支付溢价。

第三，不断迭代，孜孜不倦，持续不断，年复一年地改进产品。重点关注无法复制或模仿的方面。以 iPhone 为例，这些因素包括定制芯片、卓越的硬件组件和制造技术、 数十年制作的软件框架、优先考虑出色设计的文化，以及不断扩大的生态系统，通过让客户满意而留住他们。 。建造一座他们不想离开的豪华度假村，而不是一座他们无法离开的监狱。

不要优先考虑成为第一或最便宜。优先考虑成为最好的。这是一个简单的策略。这是极其艰难的执行。

★

entry.summary: 我不知道有多少人会对这种切换感到恼火，甚至是彻头彻尾的愤怒，但这将比大多数“*iPhone 应该已经切换到 USB-C*”的人多*很多*。支持者期望。
entry.content:
蒂姆·哈德威克（Tim Hardwick）为 MacRumors 撰稿：

Apple 可能会为 iPhone 15 Pro 型号提供 USB-C 数据传输配件电缆，该电缆能够实现高达 40Gbps 的 Thunderbolt 或 USB4 速度。这是Kosutami 的最新说法，他在 Twitter（现在的 X）上发布了该电报的详细信息。据爆料者称，该线缆长度为 0.8 米，比苹果现有的 Thunderbolt 4 Pro 线缆（1.8m）还要短，据称最高支持 150W 充电。据称，苹果将单独出售该电缆。

以免您认为 Apple 单独销售 Thunderbolt 4 电缆很划算，请注意，Thunderbolt 4 电缆非常昂贵。苹果目前出售两款：180 万颗的售价为 129 美元，300 万颗的售价为 159 美元。我去年买了一把 Razor 生产的 80 万块，感觉和质量与苹果的非常相似，亚马逊目前售价 46 美元。 （如果您正在市场上购买 Thunderbolt 4 电缆，这是一个让我致富的附属链接。）Monoprice 的 1m Thunderbolt 电缆（橡胶，非编织）售价 30 美元。苹果自己的 80 万条 Thunderbolt 3 电缆售价 39 美元。我猜测 Apple 推出的这款新型 0.8m Thunderbolt 4 线缆售价为 99 美元。对于苹果来说，为每部 iPhone 15 Pro 配备一条昂贵（又粗、又硬、又短）的数据线是非常愚蠢的。

提供这样的电缆并在手机上提供 Thunderbolt 4 性能的原因是为了数据传输，特别是视频传输。直到今年 iPhone 仍然坚持使用 Lightning，最大的挫败感是 4K 视频文件非常大，但 USB 2.0 数据传输非常慢。 iPhone从2015年的6S机型开始就能够拍摄4K视频，随着图像质量逐年提高，Lightning的数据传输限制似乎越来越不协调。 1

当我们在 2020 年和 2021 年使用 iPhone 拍摄 WWDC 远程脱口秀节目的新冠时代剧集时，我遇到过两次这种情况。这段视频看起来很棒，但从手机上传输下来需要几个小时。迄今为止，iPhone 提供的专业品质摄像机仅限于消费者级别的数据传输速率。

不过，说到“专业版”，更快的数据传输速度可能确实是今年 P Pro 的主要功能。哈德威克继续说道：

因此，关于 iPhone 15 系列的 USB-C 端口功能的猜测仍然盛行，除了从 Lightning 端口切换到 USB-C 端口之外，没有什么是确定的。有传言称，iPhone 15 包装盒中提供的电缆仅限于 USB 2.0 数据传输速度，为 480 MBps，与 Lightning 相同。

相比之下，根据郭最初的说法，iPhone 15 Pro 机型预计将配备具有 USB 3.2 或 Thunderbolt 3 传输速度的电缆。 ChargerLab的图像显示，部分 iPhone 15 型号将配备 Thunderbolt/USB 4 重定时器芯片，这似乎证实了 Pro 型号的更高速数据传输的传言。

据报道，每台 iPhone 15 的包装盒中都会包含一条编织 USB-C 充电线，该充电线比当前 iPhone 型号附带的 Lightning 线更粗（即更耐用）且长 50%。据传，这些电缆的颜色与可能的新 iPhone 颜色相匹配，至少有黑色、白色、黄色、蓝色和橙色。

即使大多数 Pro 型号 iPhone 买家也从不通过电缆传输数据，因此以这种方式将 iPhone 15 Pro 型号与非 Pro 型号区分开来感觉很公平。所有新型号都配备颜色匹配的编织电缆将是一个不错的选择（并且与其他最新产品保持一致，例如 M1 iMac 和 M2 MacBook Air，均配备颜色匹配的编织电缆）。但事实上，其中一些手机（非专业版）可能仅支持 USB 2 速度（480 Mbps），而其他手机（专业版）将支持高达 Thunderbolt 4（40 Gbps - 大约快 80 倍），但所有端口和电缆连接器在肉眼看来都是一样的，这只表明“USB-C”是多么令人困惑。 Glenn Fleishman 2021 年的标题仍然一如既往地贴切：“ USBefuddled：解开 USB-C 标准和电缆的鼠巢”。

在我撰写有关转向 USB-C 的文章时，让我预测一下当两周后正式宣布时，人们的反应会如何。使用 iPhone 拍摄的少数电影制片人（与 iPhone 用户总数相比较少）将会感到高兴。大量的书呆子，甚至是半书呆子，他们携带多个计算设备旅行并且只希望所有设备上都有 USB-C 充电连接器，他们会很高兴。但绝大多数沉默的普通iPhone用户呢？我认为大多数 USB-C 支持者都不会预见到会出现强烈反对，因为有人指责这一转变是苹果公司的圈钱行为，目的是让人们用来自苹果公司的 30 美元新 USB-C 电缆替换所有的 Lightning 电缆。苹果商店。

亲爱的读者，您当然知道 USB-C 是一种行业标准，您可以从 Apple 以外的商店购买高质量的电缆。我想不是每个人都知道这一点。即使是那些从苹果以外的公司购买新 USB-C 充电线的人也可能会抱怨是否需要购买新充电线。

当苹果公司在 2012 年将 iPhone 5 的 30 针 iPod 连接器改用 Lightning 接口时，引起了很多抱怨。那是一个端口交换机，你可以很容易地看到新的有多好。 （旧的 30 针连接器和端口在现代人看来确实很荒谬。）乍一看，USB-C 看起来并不比 Lightning 更好，也几乎没有什么不同。我的直觉是，自 2012 年以来，“新 iPhone 连接器”方面并没有发生太大变化，除了事实上，现在的 iPhone 用户比当时多了 10 亿多，因此，现有的 Lightning 电缆可能有数十亿条。使用。典型用户更看重的是能够继续使用他们已经拥有的旧电缆（和充电器） 2 — 在他们的床边、在他们的厨房、在他们的桌子上、在他们的汽车里、在他们的背包和钱包里——而不是减少数量他们生活中需要的不同类型的电缆。

我不知道有多少人会对这种转变感到恼火，甚至是彻头彻尾的愤怒，但人数会比大多数“ iPhone 应该已经切换到 USB-C ”支持者预期的要多3 。对于我来说，我很乐意接受大大提高的数据传输速度。但我不会接听 1-800-MY-APPLE 电话。

  1. 史蒂文·索德伯格 (Steven Soderbergh) 于 2017 年使用 iPhone 7 拍摄了故事片《Unsane》 。它看起来很棒——故意带有颗粒感，以复古 16 毫米电影的方式——但令人难以置信的是，他们花了多少时间等待从 iPhone 上传输素材。 ↩︎

  2. 值得注意的是，许多 iPhone 用户将能够继续使用现有的充电线——如果他们一直使用 MagSafe 而不是 Lightning。我认为这是苹果等了这么久才将 iPhone 切换到 USB-C 的最大原因。 （iPad Pro 五年前从 Lightning 切换到了。）我认为他们想先推出 MagSafe，让人们在给 iPhone 充电的地方积累一些 MagSafe 电缆，然后从 Lightning 切换到 USB-C。三年的 iPhone（12、13、14）已经配备了 MagSafe，因此这大约是大多数用户的平均升级周期。但有趣的是，我家里的普通人不使用 MagSafe，他们使用 Lightning，可能是因为电缆更便宜。 ↩︎︎

  3. 还有更多“看看苹果强迫 iPhone 用户购买什么”的标题。 ↩︎︎

entry.title: 科利德
entry.content:
感谢 Kolide 上周对 DF 的赞助。在最终用户设备上安装操作系统更新应该很容易。毕竟，这是每个员工都能实现良好安全性的最简单但最有效的方法之一。 On top of that, every MDM solution promises that it will automate the process and install updates with no user interaction needed. entry.title: Adobe Co-Founder John Warnock Dies at 82
entry.content:
Clay Risen, reporting for The New York Times:

John Warnock, a founder of Adobe Systems whose innovations in computer graphics, including the ubiquitous PDF, made possible today's visually rich digital experiences, died on Aug. 19 at his home in Los Altos, Calif. He was 82.

The cause was pancreatic cancer, Adobe, which Dr. Warnock started in 1982 with Chuck Geschke, said in a statement.

It was just a month ago that pancreatic cancer took Kevin Mitnick, and I remarked on how many people this specific cancer has taken of late.

Until Dr. Warnock and Adobe came along, desktop printing was an arduous, expensive and unsatisfying endeavor. Users relied on either a screechy dot-matrix printer, with its pixelated text, or a specialized typesetting machine, which could cost $10,000 and take up most of a room.

Dr. Warnock developed protocols that came loaded into desktop printers themselves, and that accurately rendered what a computer sent them. Adobe's first such protocol, PostScript, went into Apple's revolutionary LaserWriter, released in 1985, and within a few years it was the industry standard.

PostScript, licensed to hundreds of software and hardware companies, helped make Adobe rich. But the company was largely unknown to the public until 1993, when it released Acrobat, a program designed to render and read files in what it called a Portable Document Format, or PDF.

PDF was an enormous breakthrough, and is more relevant today than ever. A true document format for the ages. But Adobe was well on its way before 1993. Photoshop 1.0 launched in early 1990 . They began shipping their library of original PostScript fonts and the essential Adobe Type Manager software in 1989. And Illustrator 1.0 launched back in 1987, shipping with this video tour demonstrated by Warnock himself .

Warnock and Geschke understood what Steve Jobs often preached: technology alone was not enough. PostScript was — and remains ! — excellent technology. But it was not a product. The LaserWriter was a product. You hooked it up, went to File → Print in any application, and you got professional-grade 300 DPI output with no technical expertise necessary. It was as easy to print high-quality output on a LaserWriter as it was to print junk output on a slow, noisy dot-matrix printer. That was a product.

And Illustrator turned PostScript from a rather difficult but highly-capable programming language into a tool designed for use by artists. They didn't just make a nice code editor for writing PostScript. They created an app that presented a visual framework in which you directly manipulated shapes, lines, and curves as objects. Even expert Illustrator users were never exposed to PostScript directly. The Illustrator metaphor was a complete encapsulation . That too was a product, and Illustrator remains an essential tool. If Warnock and Geschke had been satisfied merely with shipping great technology alone, Adobe Systems would be a nearly forgotten Silicon Valley footnote. Instead, they pushed to make Adobe the great tool-making product company we know today.

★

entry.title: 'Giving Up the iPad-Only Travel Dream'

Jason Snell, writing at Six Colors:

In the battle between iPad and Mac, I'm a longtime member of Team Both — I use my Mac most of the day at my desk, but when I write elsewhere in the house or backyard, I switch to an iPad Pro in the Magic Keyboard case. And that iPad (in a regular case) is my primary computing device when I'm not in work mode.

I'm not at all ready to declare the “use iPad to get work done” experiment dead. With the forthcoming release of iPadOS 17, Stage Manager has thrown in a bunch of improvements that suggest the iPad's progression to more functional status continues, albeit at a pace that's a bit too slow for my liking.

But here I sit at my mother's dining room table, typing on a MacBook Air. Something has changed in my approach to travel, and I'm trying to understand just what it is and what it tells me about the trajectory of the iPad as a productivity tool.

I've written at length , multiple times, about my decidedly mixed feelings regarding the iPad — most stridently in January 2020, in a piece titled “ The iPad Awkwardly Turns 10 ”. Stage Manager is the biggest change to the iPad interface since I wrote that, and its existence certainly helps on that “power user” front. (And Stage Manager sees some nice improvements in this year's iPadOS 17.) But for me personally, I continue to find that I'm most productive when I spend my working time in front of my Mac. Gobs of people thrive using their iPads for writing and other creative endeavors. But I know I'm best off, productivity-wise, using my iPad basically as a single-tasking consumption device for long-form reading and video watching.

The reason this topic remains evergreen is that I want to use my iPad more. There's something ineffable about it. It's a thrill when I use my iPad to do something that an iPad is actually best at. I honestly think I'd be more productive if I owned no iPad at all, yet I keep trying to find ways to use it more.

So when I travel, it's never a question whether I'll pack my MacBook Pro. Even if I don't plan or want to work during a particular trip, the one-man-show nature of Daring Fireball means I feel that I need to be able to. (I was on a family vacation, preparing to head to dinner, when this news broke 12 years ago yesterday .) The question is whether I even pack my iPad Pro at all, or just go it alone with iPhone and Mac. When I'm packing, I generally wind up tossing the iPad in my bag, thinking I'll miss it if I don't. But when I do just leave the iPad at home, I don't miss it. It's confounding, though, because I'm going on a trip next week and I bet I'll take my damn iPad.

entry.title: Apple Lends Support to California 'Right to Repair' Bill
entry.content:
Brian Heater, reporting for TechCrunch:

In a surprise move, Apple this week penned a letter to California state senator Susan Talamantes Eggman, voicing support for SB 244, a “right to repair” bill currently making its way through Sacramento's State Capitol building. [...] Apple has, of course, softened its stance on right to repair legislation in recent years, including last year's addition of a Self Service Repair program . The offering, which was viewed by many as a preemptive measure against looming state and federal legislation, provides users with rental tools to repair iPhones and Macs at home.

In the letter, Apple expresses its support on the grounds of offering consumers the ability to repair their devices safely, without risking privacy or data issues. “Apple supports California's Right to Repair Act so all Californians have even greater access to repairs while also protecting their safety, security, and privacy,” the company says in a statement provided to TechCrunch. “We create our products to last and, if they ever need to be repaired, Apple customers have a growing range of safe, high-quality repair options.”

This sort of backing from a specific manufacturer is unusual — particularly from Apple. It is thus far the only major manufacturer to express its support for the bill in this manner. These kinds of statements are generally made through industry consortiums, such as TechNet.

I don't find Apple's support for this legislation surprising, but most people commenting on it do .

Dare Obasanjo :

This is less of a pivot and more of just accepting reality.

Apple pushing aesthetics such as no seams in their phones over consumer benefits like being able to replace your phone's batteries has been deemed unacceptable by a number of governments including the EU.

Regulation is coming whether they like it or not, so they might as well get some positive PR for “supporting” the regulations.

Jason Koebler, writing at 404 Media :

Apple told a California legislator that it is formally supporting a right to repair bill in California, a landmark move that suggests big tech manufacturers understand they have lost the battle to monopolize repair, and need to allow consumers and independent repair shops to fix their own electronics.

Koebler's use of “monopoly” hints at the assumption that authorized repairs are a profit center. That is true for some manufacturers in some industries. Koebler himself has copiously documented the saga with John Deere tractors . All the nonsense inkjet printer makers go through to try to keep people from using third-party replacement ink cartridges is another. That's never been Apple's reason for opposing these laws. Apple's stance is more about control.

And I'd argue that Obasanjo is missing the possibility that Apple actually thinks California's SB 244 is a well-written law. Would Apple prefer no such law at all? I think the answer is obviously yes. Providing all the necessary documentation, tools, and parts for every new device the company makes is a pain in Apple's corporate ass, and I think that’s why Apple resisted such legislation. From their perspective any such law is an unnecessary annoyance. But it's undeniably reasonable for there to be consumer protection laws, and if there are going to be Right to Repair laws that cover computing devices, those laws ought to be good ones. And the plain language of Apple's letter is that the company thinks this is a good one.

I highly doubt we're going to see any such letter from Apple to the EU endorsing their Digital Markets Act , the law that, among numerous other sweeping provisions, is poised to mandate sideloading on all phones. Apple continues to oppose the EU law requiring USB-C ports in all rechargeable devices, and that law is already passed. Apple has complied, begrudgingly, with the Netherlands's rather specific regulations regarding dating apps and in-app payments — but they've issued no praise for the law.

If Apple says they support California's SB 244 , it probably just means they actually support it.

entry.title: 'How the iMac Saved Apple'
entry.content:
Jason Snell, writing at The Verge last week, marking the iMac's 25th anniversary:

Upon its release, the iMac became so well known that it may have even eclipsed the Apple brand for a little while. It was at least a strong enough signifier that Apple began using it on other products. The iBook laptop was an obvious choice, but in 2001, the company chose to reuse the branding for its new music player, the iPod.

The iPod didn't connect to the internet, but it didn't matter. Apple was declaring that the “i” stood for another cool Apple product you'd want to buy, and people bought an awful lot of iPods. Apple began slapping the lowercase “i” in front of a lot of its hardware, software, and services, culminating in the release of the iPhone and iPad.

An astute remembrance of a seminal product. Snell rightly emphasizes how controversial some of the iMac's features were: the lack of a floppy disk drive and dropping all legacy I/O ports in favor of USB. The branding power of that “i” prefix remains so strong that I still hear people calling Apple Watches “iWatches”.

In hindsight it seems obvious that Jobs and Ive would go on to create not just numerous great new products, but to do so in new (or at least new to Apple) product categories. But they had to start somewhere. The easiest way for Apple to have failed upon Jobs's return would have been to shoot for the moon out of the gate. The next big things would come. First, they rightly decided to focus on righting the ship that was Apple's previous big thing: a desktop personal computer. Everything the company has designed, built, and shipped since can be traced back to that Bondi Blue surprise.

entry.summary: What will actually happen, I believe, is that E2EE messaging platforms like WhatsApp (overwhelmingly popular in the UK), Signal, and iMessage *will stop working and be pulled from app stores in the UK*, full stop. The UK seems to think it's a bluff; I don't.
entry.content:
Ioannis Kouvakas, writing for Just Security :

While the proposal does not specify what technical changes would require notification, these may include changes in the architecture of software that would interfere with the UK's current surveillance powers. As a result, an operator of a messaging service wishing to introduce an advanced security feature would now have to first let the Home Office know in advance. Device manufacturers would likely also have to notify the government before making available important security updates that fix known vulnerabilities and keep devices secure . Accordingly, the Secretary of State, upon receiving such an advance notice, could now request operators to, for instance, abstain from patching security gaps to allow the government to maintain access for surveillance purposes.

This is exactly where I've thought, for months, that the United Kingdom is heading with this legislation, but it's still shocking to see it described so starkly. It's like watching someone drive toward a cliff, and warning people, “ Hey, I think these guys are driving right toward that cliff ” — and yet I'm still taken aback to see them drive off the cliff.

It's a complete fantasy that E2EE can be toggled like a light switch and still allow messages to be delivered. The end-to-end encryption isn't a sugar coating, some sort of extra layer of protection — it's fundamental to the messaging protocols themselves. It has to be, when you think about it. If it were possible for, say, Signal, to silently disable E2EE but still have messages go through, how could users ever trust the service? You could neither trust that what you were sending would be delivered securely, nor that what you received wasn't intercepted by an interloper. There's an explicit guarantee with all of these E2EE messaging platforms that messages can only go through securely . Removing E2EE wouldn't require some mere tweak to the protocols, it would require replacing the protocols entirely (with inherently insecure ones).

And the notion that security updates, for every user in the world, would need the approval of the UK Home Office just to make sure the patches weren't closing vulnerabilities that the government itself is exploiting — it boggles the mind. Even if the UK were the only country in the world to pass such a law, it would be madness, but what happens when other countries follow?

As I see it, the most likely outcome is that the UK passes the law, thinking that the grave concerns conveyed to them by the messaging services are overblown. That the platform providers are saying they can't comply but they really just mean they don't want to comply because it's just difficult, not impossible. And when it becomes law, the platforms will hand it off to the nerds, the nerds will nerd harder, and boom, the platforms will fall into compliance with this law. That's what they think will happen. What will actually happen, I believe, is that E2EE messaging platforms like WhatsApp (overwhelmingly popular in the UK), Signal, and iMessage will stop working and be pulled from app stores in the UK , full stop. The UK seems to think it's a bluff; I don't.

Perhaps the argument — as made by Kouvakas — that these changes would run afoul of international law will resonate with the UK in a way that technical arguments, thus far, have not.

1.2 User-Generated Content

  • A method for filtering objectionable material from being posted to the app
  • A mechanism to report offensive content and timely responses to concerns

Apps that contain or feature UGC, including apps which are specialized browsers or clients to direct users to a UGC platform, must implement robust, effective, and ongoing UGC moderation that:

  • Conducts UGC moderation, as is reasonable and consistent with the type of UGC hosted by the app; [...]

Blocked users can see those tweets by just opening a private/incognito browser tab as it stands. But if Musk wants to truly “delete” the block feature, he's going to run right into Apple and Google's app store rules. entry.summary: Disney was, and should remain, a serious engineering company.
entry.content:
My Dithering co-host Ben Thompson referenced this famous 1957 Disney org/strategy chart in a (very good) Stratechery post this week. I just now added a link to it in the footnote regarding company org charts in my Disney/Apple piece from yesterday, but it feels worth a post of its own.

At the center of the Disney business in the 1957 chart were theatrical films. Everything else — TV, music, magazines and comics, and the then-new Disneyland — funneled into and revolved around the theatrical films.

Lesser known is this 1967 revision . Or at least lesser known to me — I hadn't seen it before today. Walt Disney died in 1966, so this chart reflects the company as he left it. The differences from the 1957 chart that strike me:

  • Disneyland moved closer to the core of the company, nearly rivaling the motion picture studio in centrality.

  • “Disney World Florida” is tucked down in the corner, but wouldn't open until October 1971. The trend is obvious: theme parks (including, eventually, floating ones 1 ) would replace movies as the core of the company.

  • Unfamiliar to me was a box named “Mineral King”, illustrated with a skiing Goofy. Turns out this was to be a ski resort in Sequoia National Forest in California, with land rights granted by the National Forest Service in 1965. Embroiled in lawsuits from the no-fun Sierra Club for a decade, Disney abandoned the project in 1976.

  • “Comic strips” are listed separately from “publications” on both charts. I'm old enough to remember reading the newspaper comics page daily, but not old enough to remember when Mickey and pals were on them. Pre-TV, a daily newspaper comic strip filled the role that social media does today: a free way to engage everyone with small nuggets of entertainment. 2

Lastly, WED Enterprises — aka Imagineering — is a big part of the 1967 chart, but wasn't even listed on the 1957 one. [ Update: WED was a private company owned by Walt, personally, until 1965, which explains its omission from the 1957 chart for the Disney company.] Disney was, and should remain, a serious engineering company. In 1967, WED engineers were creating everything from theme park animatronics to transportation systems. Sounds familiar . Queue Alan Kay's adage: “The best way to predict the future is to invent it.” Also, the Cook Doctrine : “We believe that we need to own and control the primary technologies behind the products we make.”

  1. It's kinda bananas that Disney's theme park and cruise line websites are still subdomains of go.com. Not to mention that the root-level go.com site is so bare-bones that it isn't even served using HTTPS. Disney's go.com domain name is a vestige of the late 1990s “portal” craze — but Disney abandoned the portal itself in 2001 . ↩︎

  2. In October 1930, near the outset of the strip's decades-long run and only two years after Mickey debuted in Steamboat Willie , there was a bizarrely dark week-long storyline where each day's gag involved Mickey trying to kill himself because Minnie had left him for another mouse. Jiminy. ↩︎︎

entry.summary: I don't think Apple has any such interest or appetite. Nor do I think Disney envisions its own future as anything but the independent company it has been since Walt and Roy Disney founded The Disney Brothers Cartoon Studio 100 years ago.
entry.content:
Kim Masters and Alex Weprin, writing for The Hollywood Reporter under the headline “ A Disney Sale to Apple? Don't Count It Out This Time ”:

There clearly is no buyer like Apple, which is sitting on $62 billion in cash and cash equivalents and has a $2.8 trillion market cap. And while it may be very true that Apple doesn't want to buy a studio, maybe it would want to buy this studio — the one that, despite the challenges of the moment, has a vault full of priceless IP and remains the most valuable brand in entertainment.

And there has been a long-standing “special relationship” between Disney and Apple: Steve Jobs served on Disney's board of directors from 2006 until his death in 2011. Iger joined Apple's board shortly after Jobs died. He resigned from that position Sept. 10, 2019, the same day Apple officially announced that it was getting into the content business through its Apple TV+ service.

I do not think Apple has any interest in buying Disney. Apple frequently acquires small companies — on average, about once per month . Many of these acquisitions are so quiet they get no press coverage whatsoever, which is how Apple likes it. When acquisitions are noted, the company has a boilerplate response : “Apple buys smaller technology companies from time to time, and we generally do not discuss our purpose or plans.” They'd need a longer statement if they bought Disney.

Beats, of course, was the exception to the rule. At $3 billion in 2014 , it remains, by far, Apple's largest-ever acquisition. Disney's current market cap is $158 billion . I'm in no way arguing that Apple couldn't afford to buy Disney, even at a generous markup, but rather that enormous industry-shuffling acquisitions like that aren't what Apple does, nor, in my opinion, should do. Apple has a very distinct company culture and focus. PA Semi, which Apple acquired with relatively little fanfare for a mere $278 million in 2008, is Apple's style of acquisition. Apple is not comprised of divisional fiefdoms like Microsoft, 1 which is buying Activision for $69 billion , or Amazon, which bought its way into the grocery store market by acquiring Whole Foods for $14 billion . Manu Cornet's classic 2011 comic strip illustrating tech company org charts remains apt, and is only funny because it's accurate. 2

Disney, too, has a very distinct company culture and focus. And there are some obvious areas where Disney's and Apple's cultures overlap: they are both family-friendly iconic brands with outsized cultural influence, with reputations for industry-leading design and engineering. What each company does, they strive to do best . And because they prioritize quality over all else, both companies have built enormous devoted customer bases that are really more like fan bases. The reason the notion of an Apple-Disney acquisition has any legs at all is that it's not crazy. If Apple were to buy a major entertainment/media company, they'd probably want Disney. Why drink Veuve Clicquot when you can afford Dom Perignon? If you're going to buy, buy the best. 3 4

And if Disney were to look for a buyer, I can't think of a single big-enough-to-afford-it company other than Apple that they would want to sell to. Berkshire Hathaway is the only other big-enough company I can think of that might be trusted to let Disney be Disney. But Berkshire today holds no Disney stock at all , which strongly suggests Warren Buffett would have no interest in buying the whole company at its current price. Berkshire does, though, own 6 percent of Apple's stock, 5 so they would, by proxy, own a sizable stake in Disney if ... Apple bought Disney.

I just don't think Apple has any such interest or appetite. Nor do I think Disney envisions its own future as anything but the independent company it has been ever since Walt and Roy Disney founded the Disney Brothers Cartoon Studio 100 years ago.

  1. Microsoft and Apple, forged in the image of their founders, have long been opposites in so many regards. Their contrasting strategies regarding large acquisitions exemplify that. Microsoft has made eight acquisitions larger than Apple's $3 billion purchase of Beats (all prices in billions): Activision Blizzard ($69), LinkedIn ($26), Nuance ($20), Skype ($8.5), ZeniMax ($8.1), GitHub ($7.5), Nokia ($7.2), and aQuantive ($6.3). I'd even toss in Minecraft-maker Mojang at $2.5 billion, which is just under the price Apple paid for Beats. Would Microsoft consider buying Disney? I think they might, especially if Disney's stock dips further. (Let's put aside the regulatory hurdles such a deal would obviously face — Microsoft seems to relish such battles.) Microsoft is big in gaming, of course, but stands alone amongst Apple, Amazon, and Google with no foothold in streaming video. Would Disney consider selling itself to Microsoft? I sure hope not. ↩︎

  2. Although I think that if redrawn today, Meta/Facebook's cartoon org chart ought to look more like a cross between Apple's and Amazon's. The buck stops with Zuck. And while we know the bullseye in the 2011 Apple chart was Steve Jobs, Apple's organization today is not that much more hierarchical than it was then. I'd draw it more like a small council in the center, rather than a singular figure. But it's still spoke-and-hub. Also worth noting: Walt Disney's 1957 business strategy chart , and a 1967 follow-up . (Disney died in 1966, so this latter chart describes the company as he left it.) ↩︎︎

  3. Amazon bought MGM for $8.5 billion two years ago, and while Apple was rumored to have considered it , that never made much sense to me outside the fact that Phil Schiller is perhaps an even bigger James Bond fan than I am. ↩︎︎

  4. OK, here's a what-if for the ages: What if Apple, not Disney, had bought Pixar? Practically speaking the timing would seemingly have made it impossible. Disney bought Pixar for $7.4 billion January 2006, a full year before the iPhone was announced. Apple was thriving by that time — the Mac had completed its software transition from classic Mac OS to Mac OS X, and was beginning its hardware transition from PowerPC to Intel; the iPod was a cultural sensation and smash hit; and the company's foray into its own retail stores was proving to be an, err , genius decision. But Apple circa 2006 was not acquire another company for $7.4 billion thriving. In October 2005 Apple announced its then-best-ever financial year : $14 billion in revenue, $1.3 billion in profit. Apple's fiscal 2022 , for comparison: $316 billion in revenue, and a smooth $100 billion in profit. Apple today generates more profit every 5 days than it did in the entire year of 2006. Apple's market cap in January 2006: $60 billion. Today: $3,000 billion.

    Not to mention that Apple had no strategic reason to acquire Pixar in 2006. Apple TV+ didn't launch until 2019. The iTunes Store didn't even start renting movies until 2008 . Jobs selling Pixar (in which he owned over $1 billion in stock at the price it sold to Disney) to Apple would have looked fishy, to say the least. Also not to mention that Disney held unique leverage over Pixar's ability to shop itself to other potential suitors — Disney didn't own Pixar, but they did own the intellectual property for all of the movies Pixar had made to date: Toy Story , A Bug's Life , Monsters Inc. , Finding Nemo , The Incredibles , and the then-upcoming Cars , Ratatouille , WALL-E , and Up . Buying Pixar without acquiring those rights would have been like, well, buying Disney today without acquiring Mickey Mouse, Snow White, Star Wars, and Marvel.

    But if we wave all that inconvenient historical timing away, in the abstract it's easy today to imagine Pixar as a film studio ( and engineering ) subsidiary of Apple. It would be both a perfect cultural and strategic fit. ↩︎︎

  5. I was well aware that Berkshire Hathaway owns a 6 percent stake in Apple, but until I looked at this list of its holdings , I had no idea that Berkshire's Apple holdings account for 46 percent of its entire portfolio. That's not to say Apple accounts for 46 percent of Berkshire's entire value — only its public stock holdings. But still, that's astonishing. Warren Buffett has always measured Berkshire's success against the S&P 500. Apple is currently weighted at about 7 percent in the S&P 500. As AAPL goes, so go Berkshire's odds of beating the S&P 500 in the next few years. * ↩︎︎

    * While we're talking about Berkshire Hathaway, let's celebrate the glory that is their website . I'm not joking. It is a perfect distillation and reflection of the company and its values. Anyone who doesn't appreciate it as a nearly perfect website is the sort of fool who doesn't recognize that, sometimes, a good slice of buttered toast is just the thing and all you need.
